message: I always enjoy the opportunity to meet and talk with constituents of all ages. I recently visited Memorial High School to discuss national security, health care, and the role the federal government plays in our lives. I'm so proud of our TX-07 students and their enthusiasm for the legislative process! Go Mustangs!
Today, we remember those who have fallen in the line of duty. Thank you to all of the brave men and women who have served our country.

Today I joined thousands of Houstonians at our Veterans Cemetery to honor all those who sacrificed their lives for our nation and our freedom. Our prayers are with their families, and we will honor their sacrifice by working every day to preserve, protect and defend our Constitution and our great nation.

America is very fortunate to have General Mattis as our Secretary of Defense.  One of the most meaningful parts of my job as your representative is to recommend outstanding young men and women to our nation's military academies.  I stay in touch with each one of them and support them in every way I can throughout their career in the military.  We are blessed to have these young men and women dedicate their lives to defend our freedom.

Last night, the Zyroll family opened up their home for their neighbors and friends to gather and discuss their concerns. I had the chance to meet with these #TX07 residents and learn more about the issues that impact their families.
NA

Each year, I have the privilege of nominating young men and women to our nation’s service academies. Yesterday, I hosted a reception to congratulate the 6 students from Texas' 7th Congressional district to honor their commitment to service These students represent the best and brightest of our district and I commend them for answering the call to serve their country. I wish them the best of luck in their promising futures, and I am honored to recommend this year’s class of 2021 appointees!
My good friend Dan Patrick stopped by the office today. It was great to visit with a fellow Texan in DC!

Ana's piece, "Chasing the Storm", was selected as this year's winning submission for the Congressional Art Competition. Her work will be displayed for 1 year at the U.S. Capitol and she will be visiting D.C. later this month as we recognize this achievement. Congratulations Ana!   http://www.houstonchronicle.com/neighborhood/katy/news/article/Taylor-High-School-artist-s-work-displayed-at-11199829.php

Exciting day in the Space City! Today, Vice President Pence helped announce NASA's newest class of astronauts. These men and women were selected from 18,300 applicants and will continue training at Johnson Space Center in August. Congratulations to these new astronauts and thank you to Vice President Pence for his strong support of America's space program!

70 cents of every tax dollar immediately goes out the door for mandatory spending like Medicare, Social Security, and interest on the debt. Balancing the federal budget and paying off the national debt is urgent.

The southwest border is the first defense against drug smuggling and human trafficking. Today, I questioned Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein on the resources necessary to secure our border and keep our nation safe.
NA

It was such an honor to receive the inaugural Champion of Aerospace and Science Award from the Coalition for Aerospace and Science (CAS). The CAS is an alliance of industry, university and science organizations that are committed to supporting the vision and mission of NASA. As Chairman of the Commerce, Justice, Science Appropriations Subcommittee, I oversee the funding of the national space agency and I'm proud to support their efforts.

Last night, my staff and I attended the #CongressionalBaseballGame to support this great charity event. We were proud to support #TeamScalise and continue to keep him in our thoughts and prayers.   Yesterday, I voted for H. Res. 385 which expresses gratitude for the heroic actions of the Capitol Police officers and first responders in the June 14th attack on Members of Congress. We are hoping for a full recovery for all who were injured. I'm proud of our law enforcement officers and thankful for their bravery.
Honored to join hundreds of veterans and their families at the Korean War Commemoration Ceremony tonight in Houston.
Thank you to the Air Line Pilots Association and the good people at Bush Intercontinental Airport for the opportunity to learn more about keeping American's safe in the skies.

As Tropical Storm Cindy churns in the Gulf of Mexico, now is the time to review the proper emergency management procedures. Make sure to read over these tips from ReadyHarris and sign up for alerts so you and your family can stay up-to-date on all weather developments.   http://prepare.readyharris.org/Portals/24/Documents/2017_Hurricane%20Brochure_web.pdf?ver=2017-05-09-101425-630
Houston has the highest number of human trafficking victims nationwide. As CJS Chairman, I'm committed to providing the FBI the necessary resources to combat this growing epidemic.

When members from the armed services return home, they often find themselves struggling with the aftermath of being on the battlefield. This year, I included language in the MilCon VA Appropriations bill that requires the VA to work with research universities and hospitals to continue their efforts and knowledge about suicide prevention, post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), traumatic brain injury (TBI) and substance use disorders. With this information, we can provide better care and services for those who served our country fearlessly.   In recognition of #PTSDAwarenessDay, I am proud to support our veterans for their selfless service and the care they need when they come home.

It was an honor to receive the Bob Hoover Freedom to Fly Award from the AOPA: your freedom to fly this week! Texas is home to thousands of pilots and aircraft owners which makes the general aviation legislation that comes before Congress even more meaningful for this important sector of our state's economy.

Ensuring that the United States remains the leader in space exploration and scientific research is very important to me. My appropriations bill ensures that NASA has the resources they need to complete important missions.

Ensuring our armed forces have the resources they need to protect and defend our national security is of the utmost importance, particularly after years of drastic cuts to our military. This year’s Defense Appropriations bill reaffirms our commitment to addressing threats overseas so the United States can act swiftly and prioritize the safety of Americans.
Let freedom ring from sea to shining sea. Have a happy and safe Independence Day!
How cool is this car I got to ride in at the Villages Independence Day Parade! Thanks so much for having me and I hope everyone has a safe and happy 4th of July!

Human trafficking is one of the fastest growing crimes in the world and Houston has the highest number of human trafficking victims nationwide. This is a devastating reality that requires immediate and swift action.  Today, the House passed 3 bills to combat human trafficking and I am proud to support these efforts. Each of these measures ensures that our law enforcement agencies have access to the resources and necessary funds to combat this heinous threat. Cracking down on human trafficking through increased prevention and detection will elicit real results and relief for victims.

Today, the Energy and Water Appropriations bill was approved by the House Appropriations Committee. I included language in the legislation to help complete Houston's crucial flood control projects like Brays Bayou.
At 9 am CT, the House Appropriations Committee will be marking up Rep. Culberson's Commerce, Justice, and Science Appropriations bill. Watch live here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOILwIZ2yAY

As Chairman of the Commerce, Justice, Science Appropriations Subcommittee, I am proud of the work we have done to prioritize national security, fund NASA, crack down on crime and invest in scientific innovation for the fiscal year 2018. Today, the full House Appropriations committee is marking up this bill.   Tune in if you can!  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOILwIZ2yAY

As a native Texan and history buff, I cannot allow the Battleship Texas, a state treasure, to sit in disrepair. This piece of floating history is the last remaining battleship to participate in both World War I and World II. It serves as a memorial to the bravery and sacrifice of our servicemen.

In 2015, Houston METRO and I worked together to ensure your voice is heard as new transportation solutions are being considered. In this year's fiscal year 2018 Transportation, Housing and Urban Development (THUD) appropriations bill I included language to fulfill this agreement. Read more below.   https://culberson.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398732

Members of the National African American Clergy Network including, Houston Reverend Dr. Kirbyjon Caldwell of Windsor Village United Methodist Church, stopped by the office today. We had a productive conversation about the health care and financial services concerns of their congregations.

We had a packed house this morning! Houston members of the Korean American Civic Empowerment (KACE) group stopped by the D.C. office today to discuss their work to promote active civic engagement of the Korean American community both in Houston and across the country. We had a wonderful visit and I enjoyed the opportunity to hear their concerns.

Human trafficking is a deplorable and despicable crime. Unfortunately, the city of Houston has the highest number of human trafficking victims. Congress is acting to end this crisis and drop the hammer on human traffickers.   I am proud to join my colleagues in the House and I will continue to do everything I can to help deliver justice to these victims.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Etwg5CNB7Ro

Securing our country's borders is, and always has been, one of my top priorities. My colleague and Chairman of the Homeland Security Committee Michael McCaul introduced the Border Security for America Act today. I'm proud to be a cosponsor of this legislation, particularly for the relief this bill can deliver to the State of Texas.
House Republicans are focused on the issues that matter to you and our record proves it. Read more at https://www.didyouknow.gop/.
Enjoyed my visit this morning!

Today marks the 227th Birthday of the United States Coast Guard, founded in 1790 by Alexander Hamilton. We express appreciation to the Coast Guard men and women who risk their lives to save others in danger at sea, enforce the Nation's treaties and laws, protect the marine environment, ensure a safe and efficient marine transportation system, and conduct national defense missions worldwide. We support the Coast Guard in remaining "Semper Paratus--Always Ready" as it meets the nation's 21st century demands.
NA
Attorney General Sessions and I have had several productive meetings to discuss securing our border, enforcing our laws and cutting funding to sanctuary cities.

I had the pleasure of addressing Houston area AIPAC members today to discuss the importance of protecting the U.S.-Israel relationship. Israel is our greatest ally and we must stand together to defend democracy and freedom.
Today, I had a productive meeting with the Houston Chronicle Editor Jeff Cohen and his team to discuss issues important to #TX07.
The hatred and violent bigotry in Charlottesville today is intolerable & inexcusable. I join all Americans in condemning these abominable & horrifying acts of violence.

As a child growing up in Houston, I watched the moon landing just a few miles away from the Manned Spaceflight Center, now known as Johnson Space Center. Today, I visited JSC as the Commerce, Justice and Science Appropriations Subcommittee Chairman that is responsible for funding NASA. Investments in NASA ensure that the United States leads the way in space exploration and continues to go where no man has gone before.

Did you know over 82,000 jobs in Houston are in the oil and gas industry? My district encompasses the energy corridor, which plays a big part in the Texas economy. This afternoon I visited Citgo to discuss how smart energy policy can help the industry thrive and protect #TX07 jobs.

I applaud Texas A&M for cancelling the white supremacist rally.  There is no place in this country for Neo Nazis, the KKK or any other hateful ideologies.  America's greatest strength is equal justice for all.  Let's all work together to drive out violence and racial superiority and guarantee the rule of law for all Americans.

Thank you to Durga Agrawal and his expert team at Piping Technology & Products for showing me how they succeed against tough foreign and domestic competition.  I work every day to protect and create more great jobs in Houston by cutting taxes and reducing burdensome regulations.

TX07 small business owners joined me to discuss the tax obstacles they face every day. The House will be tackling tax reform when we return in September, and I'm glad I had the opportunity to hear stories from our local businesses. We have to change the tax code so it is easier for small businesses to succeed. The key to unlocking American innovation is getting the government out of the way.

As Tropical Depression Harvey continues to develop in the Gulf, please take time to update your emergency plan.  You can sign up for email and text alerts at www.readyhoustontx.gov/alerts. You can also find useful information at: http://www.houstonemergency.org/harvey/

We had a productive conversation yesterday about Houston's transportation needs at the #tagSynergy17 forum.  I will continue to work with the Houston delegation to improve the region's infrastructure.

I have just been briefed by the National Hurricane Center and the Harris County Flood Control District on the latest predictions for Hurricane Harvey. We should be prepared for extended heavy rainfall in the Houston area over a five to seven day period beginning this weekend. Please stock up on food, water, and all other essentials. For the most current and accurate information, I encourage you to rely on the National Hurricane Updates, Harris County Flood Control District, and ReadyHarris. Please pay particular attention to the flood gauges nearest your home, which can be found at https://www.harriscountyfws.org.

As you and your family are weathering the effects of Hurricane Harvey, please take a moment to review what resources are available to you once the storm has passed.  Please stay safe and continue to monitor all local elected officials and agencies updates during the storm.   https://culberson.house.gov/constituentservices/flood-victim-resources.htm
Houstonians, please stay safe and continue to monitor all updates from local officials and agencies.
Please be careful if you are on the roads and drive with extreme caution.
This tornado just tore through our Copperfield neighborhood. There's been damage to homes, cars, and trees. Please make sure to stay inside and be safe!
Please stay safe and follow this advice.

It is imperative that you stay up to date as Harvey continues to pass over and through the great state of Texas. Continue to monitor all updates from FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency, ReadyHarris, Houston TranStar, City of Houston Office of Emergency Management, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Weather Service as well as local and state officials. This storm has already caused catastrophic damage to the state.

The following locations have been opened as shelters. Check the list below and see if there is one nearby. Remember, flood waters are extremely dangerous to drive through.   HOUSTON AREA SHELTERS:   Golden Acres Baptist Church 2812 Pansy Street Pasadena, TX 77503  North Shore High School 9th Grade Campus 13501 Holly Park Drive Houston, Texas 77015   American Legion Hall Crosby 14890 FM 2100 Rd. Crosby, TX   MO Campbell Center 1865 Aldine Bender Houston, TX 77032   Dobie High School 10220 Blackhawk Blvd Houston, TX 77089   Key Middle School 4000 Kelley St, Houston, TX 77026   Pasadena High School 206 South Shaver Pasadena, Texas 77506   Westside High School Shelter 14201 Briar Forest Dr. Houston, TX 77077   Paul Revere Middle School 10502 Briar Forest Dr, Houston, TX 77042
If you or someone you know has a boat, please see how you can help.

The Corps made this decision on their own because they have twice as much water behind the dams as they did after the Tax Day floods. I tried to persuade them to wait but they are convinced this will prevent much larger flooding later. The dams are sound and are in no danger of collapse or failure.
If you or someone you know needs shelter, please check this list for the updated locations.  http://www.readyharris.org/News-Information/Ready-Harris-News/Post/26653

Please take a moment to read the following statement released by FEMA:  All those in the areas affected by Tropical Storm Harvey should continue to follow the instructions of state, local, and tribal officials, including instructions to shelter in place or evacuate. Do not return to evacuated areas until told it is safe to do so.   This is still a dangerous storm; residents and visitors in areas potentially affected by the severe weather should continue to monitor local radio or TV stations for updated emergency information. When it is safe to do so, check on your neighbors who may require assistance, such as infants, children, older adults, people with disabilities and others with access and functional needs. Individual community members are the first line of response following a storm.    If you evacuated and have not yet returned to your home, call your insurance company. To file a flood insurance claim under the National Flood Insurance Program, contact your insurance agent immediately. You can also call 1-800-621-FEMA (3362) – select option 2 – to learn more about your policy, and be directed to the appropriate claims resource.   While immediate lifesaving and life sustaining operations are the priority for FEMA and our partners, residents and business owners in designated counties who sustained disaster related damage due to Tropical Storm Harvey, and are able to do so, can apply for assistance by registering online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov.    You may wait to register for FEMA assistance until you know whether your home is damaged. You have 60 days after a declaration to register for FEMA disaster assistance.   Registering online is the quickest way to register for FEMA assistance since the event will last several days and the full scope of damages may not be evident until the storm has passed. If you do not have access to the internet you may register by calling 1-800-621-FEMA (3362) or 1-800-462-7585 (TTY). If you use 711 relay or Video Relay Service (VRS), call 800-621-3362 directly. The toll-free telephone numbers will operate from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. (local time) seven days a week until further notice.    FEMA does not provide food assistance, including food lost due to power outages. Voluntary organizations in the disaster area may be able to help with your food needs. If you have a food-related need, dial 2-1-1 for a referral to an organization that can assist. Family and friends of those in the affected areas are urged to check social network sites like Facebook or Twitter for information about your loved ones, or use the American Red Cross’s Safe and Well program, to let family members know they are safe, or looking for loved ones. To report a missing child, contact the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC) at 1-866-908-9570. Anyone who finds an unaccompanied child who may have been separated from their parents or caregivers should contact the local police, or enter basic information and/or a photo into the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children's Unaccompanied Minors Registry or call 1-866-908-9570.

This is an excellent platform for information and helpful for connecting you with the resources you need.   https://usagov.ctacdev.com/hurricane-harvey?utm_campaign=%2B%20Disasters%20and%20Emergencies&utm_content=59505380&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter

#TX07 residents, please make sure to check this list.
Please read and review what resources are available to you and your family. We are #HoustonStrong.   https://culberson.house.gov/news/email/show.aspx?ID=D3ACL5MR2VWCGTLNWQYH5O7ABA
If you’re looking for info on how to help with #Harvey, a list of trusted organizations in Texas can be found here: txvoad.communityos.org/cms/node/104

As Hurricane Harvey has passed through Houston, the U.S. Department of Transportation has responded. $25 million dollars for emergency relief efforts have been granted to the Texas Department of Transportation to help repair and reconstruct federal-aid highways and roads on federal lands that have suffered damage due to Harvey.   We know rebuilding our city will require the work and cooperation from the local, state and federal level which is why I'm encouraged by this decision. We are #HoustonStrong.  https://grants.ost.dot.gov/public/ViewMessage.cfm?MsgID=ivd00t1m16

#TX07 residents, if you need assistance from my office please call the Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-2571. The Houston office will be closed and is without power at the moment but my D.C. staff is happy to assist however we can. Please stay safe!
Please make sure to read this notice from the Harris County Flood Control District.
NA
Thank you for your support and help! #HoustonStrong

Below are some health resources for you and your family as you are handling the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey. Please review what is available and share with your friends and neighbors.   PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY RESOURCES https://www.phe.gov/emergency/events/harvey2017/Pages/default.aspx  BEHAVIORAL HEALTH HHS has activated its Disaster Distress Helpline, a toll-free call center, that is available at 1-800-985-5990 to aid people in coping with the behavioral health effects of the storm and help people in impacted areas connect with local behavioral health professionals.  DIALYSIS Our CMS Regional and Central offices are aware and are working with state officials, local dialysis networks and local providers to address emergency dialysis patient concerns.  Patients and their families who believe their situation is not critical should contact the emergency ESRD Network phone numbers below for assistance in finding dialysis services.  There are 2 emergency numbers: • Texas ESRD Emergency Coalition (TEEC) 866-407-3773  • Emergency patient 800 Line – 877-886-4435 or 972-503-3215   MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY/ALS/NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASES MDA is available as a resource in this challenging time, and encourage your staff to refer individuals and families living with neuromuscular disease who may need your help to MDA's National Resource Center and MDA.org:  Online: https://www.mda.org/services/emergency-resources  By phone: (800) 572-1717  Email: resourcecenter@mdausa.org    We are also messaging that MDA is available to help through social media via Facebook and @MDANews and @MDA_Advocacy.  DIABETES  http://www.jdrf.org/hurricaneharvey/  Where to find Insulin for Life supplies:  • The first delivery of one pallet is for immediate distribution by the Houston Health Department to evacuees with diabetes who are sheltered at the George R. Brown Convention Center. • The second pallet will be distributed by Senator Larry Taylor’s office to the Galveston communities of Clear Creek, Friendswood, League City and Victory Lakes. • Two pallets are being delivered to the Harris County Health Department. • The fifth pallet is going to the City of Corpus Christi Health Department.  PRESCRIPTION ASSISTANCE/LIST OF OPEN PHARMACIES  https://www.healthcareready.org/rxopen?utm_source=Healthcare+Ready+Communications&utm_campaign=412ca777ce-TS+Erika+-+Alert&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_16d14078b8-412ca777ce-
NA

Please take a moment to file a claim at disasterassistance.gov. This is crucial for FEMA and and all federal efforts that will be deployed to help Houston rebuild.   https://culberson.house.gov/news/email/show.aspx?ID=D3ACL5MR2VWCHI5PKB3GKF3OBY

It is truly incredible to see how many Texans are looking for opportunities to help our fellow neighbors in their time of need. Many people have asked for guidance on how they can help and I want to make sure you see the following information that FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency released.  To volunteer with high water vehicles or boats: Call 713-881-3100 and ask for a Fire Marshal  Medical personnel can contact Remote Area Medical to help with rescue efforts.  Contact RAM at volunteers@ramusa.org or 865-579-1530.  Anyone wanting to be paid for their services:  http://www.fema.gov/about-industry-liaison-program  or Google “FEMA Industry”  For contractors looking for work, they should be directed to the State of Texas purchasing and contracting office: 512-463-3034, option 1.  Independent drivers/haulers: Coyote Broker https://www.coyote.com/ 877-6-COYOTE   877-626-9683  Group drivers/haulers: www.GSA.gov 1-844-GSA-4111 (1-844-472-4111)  Please keep in mind, there are many other ways you can help as we rebuild from Harvey. I will make sure to post other opportunities as I learn of them.
We are #HoustonStrong.
Check this fact vs. fiction list from FEMA regarding Hurricane Harvey rumors.   https://www.fema.gov/hurricane-harvey-rumor-control

As we begin to rebuild from #Harvey, my thoughts and prayers are with all who have suffered from this storm.   This is our city. We will rebuild from this and come back more united than before. I am proud to be a lifelong Houstonian and I know we will come back stronger than ever. We are #HoustonStrong.  I encourage you and your family to review this comprehensive recovery guide which has the resources that are available to you. Please share with your family, friends and neighbors.   https://culberson.house.gov/uploadedfiles/rep._culberson_harris_county_disaster_recovery_guide_8.31.17.pdf
Please remember the first step in receiving assistance from FEMA is to visit www.disasterassistance.gov and file a claim.
NA

In the wake of an unimaginable disaster, our city is stepping up to the call to help and serve our neighbors. I had the chance to visit the NRG Stadium and work with the ReadyHarris staff, Judge Ed Emmett, Robert Eckels and so many volunteers to begin rebuilding Houston.   We are #HoustonStrong. We are #TexasStrong.

This is a very important advisory for all Houston area residents!

Please read the following notice from the City of Houston. This is very important information.   Mayor Turner Issues Voluntary Evacuation Request for those who live SOUTH of I-10, WEST of Gessner, NORTH OF Briarforest, EAST of the reservoirs.   Today Mayor Turner issued a voluntary evacuation request. If you have any water inside your home, and if you live in an apartment or high rise if there is currently any water on the first floor, in an area bounded by I-10 on the north, Briar Forest on the south, Highway 6 on the west and Gessner on the east, you are asked to get out of your home and stay out for at least the next two weeks.   Given the current water releases from Barker and Addicks Reservoirs by the Army Corps of Engineers, and its intention to continue such releases at the current level, the situation on the ground is not anticipated to change for the next two weeks. The Army Corps intends to continue releases between 13,300 cfs and 16,000 cfs for at least the next two weeks.  If you have water in your home, it will be there for at least the next two weeks.  If you do not have water in your home, the Mayor and the Harris County Flood Control District said they currently do not anticipate that you will receive flood water and should be able to stay in your home.  If you do stay in your home, please continue to monitor weather conditions.   In issuing his request, the Mayor cited the risk of electrocution, structural compromise, water quality, and critters in the water (including gators, snakes and fire ants).  The Mayor acknowledged during his press conference that most of these homes had no flooding as the result of the intense rainfall we received, and were only flooded by the release of water from Addicks and Barker Reservoirs.  If you are in the voluntary evacuation area and need assistance, the City of Houston urges you to call 911.  The city will provide transportation to the NRG Park shelter for those in need of housing or residents can proceed there directly.  More information on the water levels in Addicks and Barker and the water inundation areas can be found here: https://www.hcfcd.org/flooding-floodplains/addicks-and-barker-reservoirs/  For current information on Buffalo Bayou, follow the link to " Buffalo Bayou Inundation Scenarios, August 30, 2017."

Flood Plain Management inspectors have returned from the field with some disturbing news. Supposedly there are individuals impersonating city of Houston and FEMA inspectors with the intent to rob them.  We strongly suggest that if anyone comes to your home claiming to be a federal, state, or local official, that you ask for proper identification before you allow anyone in your home.  If you suspect someone of posing as a FEMA inspector, call the toll-free Disaster Fraud Hotline at 866-720-5721 or 911 if it is an emergency.

Today, I'll be visiting neighborhoods in Katy along with representatives from FEMA. If you do not have flood insurance, there are resources available to you. Please visit www.culberson.house.gov for a guide to help with FEMA claims. We will work together to rebuild our city.

Today, I saw the resiliency of our community. I visited homes and community centers that are rebuilding after #hurricaneharvey. Thank you to everyone who shared their stories with me today. I am committed to working for all who have suffered from this storm.   We are #HoUStonStrong.
Please make sure to watch this announcement from Mayor Turner about the mandatory evacuation for parts of Houston.

I spent this afternoon with Leader Kevin McCarthy and a bipartisan group of Texas members whose districts have been impacted by Hurricane Harvey. We visited the NRG shelter and heard the stories from those that have had to evacuate their homes. A bipartisan effort to get Texas the support it needs to rebuild is already underway. We will vote on an initial emergency supplemental funding bill this week. This legislation will provide a down payment to continue life-saving emergency services, begin repairing homes that have been impacted, and provide loans for businesses and homes that need to rebuild.

Many people have been asking how they can help as #HarveyRecovery is underway and I wanted to share the following opportunities.    For ALL Food (including MREs and heater meals): • Houston Food Bank 535 Portwall St,  Houston, TX 77029 (713) 223-3700   For Individual Donations: •  Lakewood Church 3700 Southwest Fwy,  Houston, TX 77027 (713) 635-4154 **This location is taking all donations EXCEPT for clothing.  Please DO NOT send clothing here.**   •  World Harvest Outreach Seventh-Day Adventist Church 10800-A  Scott Street Houston 77047 Contact: Pastor Kenneth Goodman (713.364.9763) Receiving Donations: M-F 9:00am – 6:00pm   • Bethel Heavenly  Hands Church 12660 Sandpipers Street Houston, Texas 77035 Contact: Pastor Walter August, Jr. (713.962.6602) Receiving Donations: M-F 8:00am – 6:00pm   Additional drop-off points may be established as conditions change, so check houstonrecovers.org for more.    Volunteers:  Volunteers are still needed at the GRB Red Cross shelter, but please note that VOLUNTEERS MUST BE 18 YEARS OF AGE.   Volunteer Houston is on site helping manage volunteer operations. Please sign up for a shift at http://volunteerhouston.org/.  For those looking for opportunities to participate in recovery efforts in their own communities, the Houston Community ToolBank is a tool lending program that provides fellow non-profit organizations with access to tools for use in volunteer projects. Organizations eligible to borrow tools include:  •  Nonprofit/Charitable/Tax exempt organizations •  Schools and PTAs/PTOs •  Neighborhood associations •  Faith-based groups • Civic organizations • Government agencies  Please note that individuals are not eligible to borrow tools, and that the Houston Community Toolbank will be closed until Tuesday.  Lastly, for those who are in a position to make a financial contribution, we recommend gifts to the Hurricane Harvey Relief fund via www.ghcf.org

As announced last week, the Houston office is still closed due to flood damage. If you need assistance, please call the D.C. office at 202-225-2571. The Houston office will be closed throughout this week. As soon as the office has reopened, we will make an announcement. We appreciate your patience!

If you need assistance with filing an insurance claim, Texas State Representative Jim Murphy's office is hosting a mobile insurance claim station Tuesday, September 5th through Monday, September 11th to assist constituents. The station is in the Sears parking lot of Memorial City Mall, off of Barryknoll.The station will be open from 9 am- 6 pm daily. Representatives from the following companies will be on site:  • Texas Department of Insurance is available to assist consumers in filing claims and answering questions • Allstate • Liberty Mutual/Safeco • Travelers • Wellington • AAA

The House of Representatives has just approved an emergency disaster supplemental appropriations bill to help rebuild our communities after Hurricane Harvey.   I am grateful that House leadership has moved so quickly on this initial supplemental bill. I’d also like to thank the first responders and volunteers who traveled across the country to help Texans when they needed it most.   Help is on the way and Congress is delivering the much needed help. #HoUStonStrong #TexasTough  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AuJA-OivYsc

Please make sure to read this announcement from the US Postal Service regarding mail pick up.   http://about.usps.com/news/state-releases/tx/2017/tx_2017_0831.htm

For all #TX07 residents who live in the area, please consider attending this panel discussion tomorrow morning.   The Energy Corridor District will host a panel discussion on Hurricane Harvey recovery tomorrow morning from 8:30 A.M. to 10:00 A.M. at The Village School (Moore Gym), 2005 Gentryside Dr. Houston, TX 77077.  The event is open to the public.  Get your questions answered from professionals   *Car/Home Insurance filing *FEMA  *Choosing a contractor *Real estate questions  *Landlord obligation *Mortgage company & credit card help *How to give back *Volunteering opportunities *Home repairs *Question and Answer session We will have a professional panel to discuss how to get back on our feet and where to turn for resources. State of Texas/FEMA Disaster Recovery Centers will open Monday, Sept. 11, 2017, in Katy and Houston.   Disaster recovery centers offer in-person support to individuals and businesses that have been impacted by Hurricane Harvey.    Recovery specialists from FEMA, the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA), the State and other agencies will be at the centers to talk about assistance and to help anyone who needs guidance in filing an application. The new centers are at the following locations:   Katy Mills Mall  5000 Katy Mills Circle Katy TX 77494 Hours: Daily, 7 a.m.-7 p.m.  Greenspoint Mall  263 Greenspoint Mall Houston TX 77060 Hours: Daily, 7 a.m.-7 p.m.  Additional centers can be found by visiting www.fema.gov/DRC
If you've lost your job or are self-employed and unable to work due to Hurricane Harvey, the Texas Workforce Commission offers unemployment assistance.To apply online visit: ui.texasworkforce.org

As you are rebuilding after Hurricane Harvey, there are many resources that are available to you. There are several Disaster Recovery Centers (DRC) that have opened in Harris County to help individuals and businesses that were impacted by Harvey. There are recovery specialists from FEMA, the U.S.Small Business Administration (SBA), the State of Texas and other agencies to help answer questions regarding disaster assistance programs and assist with filing applications. Below are some recommendations before you visit a DRC and a list of locations that are located in #TX07.   Disaster recovery centers are accessible to people with disabilities. Centers have assistive technology equipment allowing disaster survivors to use amplified telephones, phones that display text, amplified listening devices for people with hearing loss and magnifiers for people with vision loss. Video Remote Interpreting is available and in-person sign language is available by request. The centers also have accessible parking, ramps and restrooms.  If possible, homeowners, renters and businesses should register with FEMA before visiting a recovery center. Eligible residents may register for assistance the following ways:  · Online at DisasterAssistance.gov.  · Phone 800-621-3362 (voice, 711/VRS-Video Relay Service) (TTY: 800-462-7585). Multilingual operators are available (press 2 for Spanish).  · Via the FEMA app, available for Apple and Android mobile devices. To download visit: fema.gov/mobile-app.  The following information is helpful when registering:  · Address of the location where the damage occurred (pre-disaster address). · Current mailing address. · Current telephone number. · Insurance information. · Total household annual income. · Routing and account number for checking or savings account (this allows FEMA to directly transfer disaster assistance funds into a bank account). · A description of disaster-caused damage and losses.   Disaster survivors can visit any of the centers for assistance. Locations of other recovery centers are online at www.fema.gov/DRC

The Harris County Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Management will be hosting a recovery fair this weekend in #TX07.   The Harvey Recovery Fair will provide important information about available disaster assistance from both governmental and non-profit organizations. Representatives from Harris County, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), the Small Business Administration (SBA) and other volunteer agencies will be available to answer questions and help residents apply for disaster assistance. Free dry food and bottled water will be available for residents attending. This week, the House passed two very important bills aimed at curbing the Iranian ballistic missile program and eradicating the terror that Hizballah inflicts on our great friends in Israel.   I am a proud cosponsor of both of these important bills which will ensure that we take steps to mitigate the growing threat the aggressive Iranian regime poses with respect to its ballistic missile programs and help bring an end to Hizballah financing its terrorist activities. These bills, the Iran Ballistic Missiles and International Sanctions Enforcement Act and the Hezbollah International Financing Prevention Amendments Act of 2017, will help ensure the safety of the United States and our allies around the world.

The House passed H.R. 3922, the Championing Healthy Kids Act, earlier today to ensure 8 million low-income children across the country continue to have health insurance. The bill provides an additional $118.5 billion to the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP). The Championing Healthy Kids Act also funds children’s access to community health centers. Community Health Centers are vitally important to neighborhoods all across Houston as they are patient-centered organizations that provide comprehensive health services to medically-underserved populations regardless of the ability to pay.

Tonight, the U.S. House of Representatives held a moment of silence in remembrance of the Sutherland Springs victims. We are reminded that this devastating act of hate does not define this community but shines a light on their resilience and unity.   Our hearts are with the families of the victims and we will continue to keep them in our thoughts and prayers.

The Houston Congressional delegation won't be the same without Ted Poe. Judge has been a longtime advocate for our city and the great state of Texas. We have worked side by side on so many different issues impacting Houston and I will miss his grit, leadership and passion.

Every day, and especially Veteran’s day, we owe the deepest debt of gratitude to our nation’s veterans for the selfless sacrifices they have made so that we may all live in a free, open and prosperous America. These bills, in addition to major VA reforms passed by the House earlier this year would have a meaningful impact on veteran’s health care, employment opportunities and access to other critical services.  Thank you to each and every veteran living in Houston and around the country for their service and unwavering dedication to our country. These individuals are true American heroes.

Had existing law been enforced, the horrific tragedy in Sutherland Springs, Texas would have never occurred.  The pure negligence of criminal history reporting into the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) has to stop.  I’m honored to join my fellow Texas legislators, Senator John Cornyn and Rep. Henry Cuellar on the #FIxNICS Act and am greatly encouraged at the bipartisan effort to hold federal and state authorities accountable to existing law.   Learn More about the Fix NICS Act and read my full statement here: https://culberson.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398793

One of the most important things the government can do is to expand our highways and improve our roads, because it's one of the only ways the government can give us back something that is so precious to each of us - our TIME. Less road congestion means clearer roads and more time with our families, on the job, and doing what we love most.  Today I had the privilege of attending the groundbreaking of the Texas Department of Transportation I-610/I-69 Interchange Reconstruction Project – an important project that will decrease the time we all spend in traffic, create jobs, and create drainage for flood mitigation.  I will continue to work to make sure federal money is available so we can expand this intersection and the rest of Houston’s highways and roads in the future. https://t.co/KQUHpknx4D #txclearlanes

Today I spoke on the House floor in support of H.J.Res 123, the Continuing Appropriations Act. The House MUST pass this Continuing Resolution to ensure that Hurricane victims are taken care of and that the federal government continues to function.   We need this C.R. to:  →  Ensure Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria survivors are compensated for the damage they’ve suffered ... →  Ensure the military has the funds it needs to operate →  Ensure the FBI and the Department of Justice have the funds they need to continue protecting the people of America against terrorism, to protect children and women against violence, to stop the scourge of opioid trafficking and abuse, and to stop the international drug cartels from pouring their drugs into this country.  My colleagues on the Appropriations Committee, along with the Houston delegation, are working arm-in-arm with the Florida delegation to create a hurricane relief package that will ensure that the people of Texas, Florida, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands are adequately compensated for their losses and that we repair the damage to our flood control infrastructure. WATCH my full speech here: http://cs.pn/2AlpyTs
